title: Keep issuer and label separate
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Currently issuer and label are [concatenated](https://github.com/andOTP/andOTP/blob/master/app/src/main/java/org/shadowice/flocke/andotp/Database/Entry.java#L128) at import time. I think it would be cleaner if issuer and label were stored separately.

This would allow showing them more nicely (with less truncation), e.g. like [how it's done in freeotp](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/179599/48661436-ffe1eb00-ea71-11e8-8708-4ff321c3ea5f.png) (which is actually where I found this project as a more active alternative!).

It would also allow things such as grouping by issuer.

title: Remove issuer from label to avoid repetition
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
For example, the otpauth URL imported via QR code for my Google account is this:

    otpauth://totp/Google:my%40email.com?secret=lolnicetry&issuer=Google

This results in the pretty ugly label `Google - Google:my@email.com`.
The [spec](https://github.com/google/google-authenticator/wiki/Key-Uri-Format#label) shows that the part before the colon is the issuer (and should match the one in the query string). So my suggestion would be to remove the `foo:` part from the label if it matches the issuer.

Hello,

I would like to request the ability to store OTP secrets within the app's own storage (/data/data/org.shadowice.flocke.andotp/) unencrypted. It seems the only way to store them without extra passwords currently is to use Android's credential storage (which has its own problems, e.g. enforcing a lockscreen)

The reason I ask for this is because my automatic backup procedure dumps the entirety of /data. If the secrets in /data are encrypted, my backups will be of limited use - I cannot import them anywhere wihout the help of a working copy of andOTP - which is not always a given. So ultimately my reason for requesting this is portability and independence.

It would be very much appreciated. Thanks!

title: Codes Provided By App Don't Work For Some Accounts
body:
#### General information

* **App version:** 0.6.0-beta2 (been using since at least 0.5.0.1 however, possibly even earlier - got from F-Droid either late last year or early this year; been letting it update since)
* **App source:** F-Droid
* **Android Version:** 7.0
* **Custom ROM:** None

#### Expected result
**What is expected?** 
All of the 2FA codes provided by the app should work as expected.
**What does happen instead?**
The 2FA codes provided by the app are denied, locking me out of some of my accounts. This happens on some of the accounts but not all. Some examples would be my Discord and Ubisoft account. My Google/Github accounts work fine however. I can access the accounts just fine with the backup codes they each provided but the 2FA codes from this app don't work at all. They worked when I first added 2FA to my accounts but as the months have gone on it has become less and less reliable.

One interesting bit of info - my Amazon account didn't work with the code the app provided but without changing it the code eventually worked after a few seconds. Maybe a timing issue? Not too well-versed on the technical side of 2FA and how it works exactly so apologies if it doesn't operate on timings at all.

I didn't backup/restore at all before I saw this issue start to happen. As a test I backed up, reinstalled the app, and restored my codes but the exact issue with the same accounts that are affected is still present, even after doing this a few times.

Used Android KeyStore authentication. Recently switched to Password / PIN but this issue started occurring while using Android KeyStore. Might have something to do with it?

As a test I used a backup code for one of my accounts and disabled 2FA. When I try to re-enable, it rejects all codes given by the app. I scanned in the QR code multiple times to make sure there wasn't any errors in reading.

title: Paper Backups
body:
This is a feature request, but I should have time / be able to implement it sometime this summer.

It would be very convenient to have access to a paper backup scheme for local secrets. Translation to words is convenient for hand transcription; most schemes get ~12 bits per word so the secret size is totally viable to just copy over by hand. This prevents concerns about accidentally saving a screenshot somewhere, printers, etc.

I would suggest that this feature should be behind some sort of password protection, to prevent the "borrows phone and screenshots secrets" attack. 

I think that this backup method (write down secrets and put them in an envelope) achieves a very desirable combination of security+convenience, and it's how I want to back up my 2fa secrets.

I understand that it is lower security than one-time backup codes; but as I understand it these cannot be implemented in a service-agnostic way.

Does this sound sane to people / is it a feature that they would also be interested in?

title: Streamline backup and restore
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Enhancement

Right now if you want to restore a file it has to be in the Download directory unless you enable 'Ask for Filename' is enable for both restores and backups. 

1.  I think 'Ask for Filename' should always be enabled for restore. This is also to confirm that the application is importing the expected file.
2. Backups should have time stamped filename enabled by default. This help with versioning and if we enable more frequent updates like in #46, it is easier to overwrite a backup that could be needed if the filename is static. If a user needs a constant filename, they can disable time stamps explicitly. 
3. One touch backups: Once the backup methodology is configured, backups should be one click and done. This is where backups should have 'Ask for Filename' disabled. As you can see, 1 and 3 conflict with each other.  
4. When a backup file is generated, it should show a transient overlay dialog with the file name and path. 
This is for confirmation that backup completed and info on what the file name is.

title: Proposal to allow automatic login
label: [Label(name="Password / PIN"), Label(name="WIP"), Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="maybe"), Label(name="security")]
body:
Currently andOTP requires you to hit enter to log you in.

This has been addressed before but was decided against due to the performance of trying to decrypt the database or having to store the length of the password.

I propopose the following(This could always be hidden behind a setting so it is opt in):

1. Add a dictionary to the app, maybe few hundred words
2. When the user enters a pin/password we randomly select a word from the list
3. We encrypt the word and store it in a file on device
4. We also encrypt the word with a key stored in the key store
5. When the user opens the app, and based on the minimum pin/password length we wait for them to enter a long enough password
6. We decrypt the keystore based file so we know what word we are comparing it
7. On each pin/password change we spin up an Async task to try to decrypt the file and compare it to the valid word
8. We allow the user to hit enter and try a full decryption as it does Currently
9. If the async task completes succesfully we automatically log the user in

This achieves a number of things, performance should remain, we are doing all tasks in background threads so the main thread should stay as it is.

We are not storing any damaging data unencrypted, and because there are hundreds of seed words posibility it would hopefully also be hard to brute force

Worst case scenario it loses the keystore key and you just lose the ability to auto login

Nice work so far! Though the Google backup feature is yet to be implemented, a new feature that would be really awesome to see in andOTP is the ability to set up authentication mode to Fingerprint or Face ID!

title: Automatic Authentication of Users
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Well, I setup PIN mode for authentication and I must say, it is just overkill, love it but a suggestion to help enhance it is, for the PIN, there should be a limit (probably between 4-10), then for the password type of authentication, you could as well set a limit too. Then here comes my second, most important and major suggestion.
After the PIN/Password has been set, I noticed that on the page that requests for the user's authentication (when the app is run), there's no `NEXT` or `ENTER` or `GO` button in that window except for the user's installed keyboard, this doesn't seem right to me because I was actually caught up in the loop asking myself where the `GO` button is on the screen and where exactly am I to click in order to continue. To be honest, most apps I've seen in recent times that have some kind of security feature, they have a `CONTINUE` button that is grayed out if nothing has been entered in the Password/PIN box and only becomes visible when the minimum or maximum number of digits has been entered in the box. title: FreeOTP migration script
body:
Hello,  
congratulations on such a nice OTP app. It has everything I want in an app, so I migrated my codes from FreeOTP to andOTP. I wrote a short script to do this.

To run the script, get the `tokens.xml` file from the FreeOTP directory on the phone, run the script with the filename as a parameter (`./freeotp_migrate.py tokens.xml`), and the script will output an andOTP-compatible plaintext JSON file. Just restore that and you're done.

Here's the script, released under the MIT license:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import base64
import json
import sys
import xml.etree.ElementTree


def read_tokens(filename):
    e = xml.etree.ElementTree.parse(filename).getroot()
    for item in e.findall("string"):
        if item.get("name") == "tokenOrder":
            continue
        token = json.loads(item.text)
        token["secret"] = base64.b32encode(
            bytes(x & 0xff for x in token["secret"])
        ).decode("utf8")

        issuer = token.get("issuerAlt") or \
            token.get("issuerExt") or \
            token.get("issuerInt")
        label = token.get("label") or token.get("labelAlt")

        if label and issuer:
            token_label = "%s - %s" % (issuer, label)
        else:
            token_label = label or issuer

        yield {
            "algorithm": token["algo"],
            "secret": token["secret"],
            "digits": token["digits"],
            "type": token["type"],
            "period": token["period"],
            "label": token_label,
        }


def main():
    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
        print("Usage: ./freeotp_migrate.py <filename>")
        sys.exit(1)

    # Dump the tokens.
    output = json.dumps(
        list(read_tokens(sys.argv[1])),
        sort_keys=True,
        indent=2,
        separators=(',', ': ')
    )

    print(output)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

If you want, I can put it on a page on my site and you can link to it, for convenience.

* [x] Authentication passwords

This is just a reminder for myself to implement some kind of encrypted/hashed storage for the authentication passwords (password and PIN) and the backup password.

Until now both are stored in plain-text which is not really secure at all.

For the authentication it should be sufficient to simply store the credentials hashed.

For the backup password this is not really an options since the hash of the password is used to generate the key, so knowing the hash would allow someone to decrypt the backups. The simplest solution would be to don't store the backup password at all and ask every time a backup is created or imported. I'm implementing a GTK+ OTP client for GNU/Linux and I would like to add support to import andOTP *encrypted* backup files.

title: Make destructive Panic trigger opt-in
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
## In short

* Change PanicKit wipe data response to opt-in rather than always-on
  * Recommended by [Guardian Project's design patterns](https://guardianproject.info/2016/01/12/panickit-making-your-whole-phone-respond-to-a-panic-button/ )
  * Avoids unexpectedly losing tokens if using an 'anxious trigger' instead of panic
  * Allows choosing to keep OTP while using a panic trigger for other apps
  * Requires a new settings activity, possibly modeled after [Zom with multiple destructive responses and a default lock response](https://github.com/zom/Zom-Android/blob/master/app/src/main/java/org/awesomeapp/messenger/ui/PanicSetupActivity.java )

Criteria | Rank | Reason
---------|---------|-------------
Impact | ★★☆ *2/3* | User-facing but niche, matches other Panic-enabled apps
Risk | ★★☆ *2/3* | Changes default, should be noted in changelog
Intrusiveness | ★★☆ *2/3* | New UI page, new strings, mostly independent

*This would build upon the excellent work in [pull request #27](https://github.com/flocke/andOTP/pull/27 ).*

---

title: Device Authentication Asked Again After Configuration Change
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
Version: 0.2.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In Settings, check "Require device credentials"

2. Swipe the app off the overview screen, so you start from a clean slate

3. Restart the app from the home screen, and authenticate against the device

4. Rotate the screen

Expected Results: Nothing out of the ordinary

Actual Results: You have to authenticate again

----

Right now, you execute [these lines](https://github.com/flocke/andOTP/blob/v0.2.2/app/src/main/java/org/shadowice/flocke/andotp/MainActivity.java#L135-L144) for every `onCreate()` of `MainActivity`. Hence, on a configuration change, we have to re-authenticate, which IMHO is aggravating.

Some options for addressing this:

- Only execute that code if `savedInstanceState` is `null`. This requires re-authentication after the task expires (~30 minutes or until manually removed from the overview screen).

- Use `onRetainNonConfigurationInstance`, the Architecture Components' `ViewModel` stuff, or a retained fragment to retain your view model (entries data, a have-we-authenticated `boolean`, etc.) across configuration changes, retrieving it in `onCreate()` via `getLastNonConfigurationInstance()`, and only re-authenticate if we need to load the data again

- Block configuration changes in the manifest via `android:configChanges` on the `<activity>` element. Personally, I don't recommend this option.

- Say that this behavior is working as intended. :-)
